# Interactive graph

<h1>Traffic Collision Situation on Different Environmental Conditions</h1>
<h4>"customize environment conditions and compare them!"</h4>


<h5>
Steps:
</h5>
<p>
1. Choose the type of environment condition you are interested in on Independent Variable dropdown button. (You can select from Weather, Speed Limit, Surface Condition, Light and Traffic Control)
</p>
<p>
2. Choose the type of collision situation. (You can select from Injury Severity and Vehicle Damage Extent)
</p>
<p>
3. Select the two levels of the environment condition you want to compare on level 1 and level 2.
</p>
<p>
4. Hover over a bar to view detailed information about percentage of collision severity at that level.
</p>
<p>
5. Choose other variables and levels of your interest to explore our results!
</p>


<div>
 <label style="color: darkblue; font-weight: bold; font-size: 12;">Independent Variable:</label>
    <select id="independentDropdown">
      <option value="Weather">Weather</option>
      <option value="Surface.Condition">Surface Condition</option>
      <option value="Light">Light</option>
      <option value="Traffic.Control">Traffic Control</option>
      <option value="Speed.Limit">Speed Limit</option>
  </select>
</div>
<div>
 <label style="color: darkblue; font-weight: bold; font-size: 12;">Dependent Variable:</label>
  <select id="dependentDropdown">
    <option value="Injury.Severity">Injury Severity</option>
    <option value="Vehicle.Damage.Extent">Vehicle Damage Extent</option>
  </select>
</div>
<div>
 <label style="color: darkblue; font-weight: bold; font-size: 12;">Chosen Level 1:</label>
  <select id="chosenindependent">
    <option >NONE</option>
  </select>
  </div>
<div>
 <label style="color: darkblue; font-weight: bold; font-size: 12;">Chosen Level 2:</label>
  <select id="chosendependent">
    <option >NONE</option>
  </select>
</div>

<div id="leftGraph"></div>
<div id="rightGraph"></div> 

<h5>
Remember: 
</h5>
<p>
 - The top graph refers to the distribution of the collision situation for environment condition level 1; the bottom graph refers to the distribution of the collision situation for environment condition level 2.
</p>
<p>
 - "Total Count" in top right corner is represent the total traffic collision in Montgomery County from 2015 to 2023.
</p>
<p>
 - Everytime you change the collision situation, re-select the levels you are interested. 
</p>
